column4: how do I tell if I'm running ubuntu 10.04 Desktop or 10.04 Server?
Depends on what features of each you're looking for.  (There's no significant difference between the two, just different packages installed)
uname -a, are you running the server kernel, or the generic kernel?
edbian/Flannel: I just ran `debootstrap --variant=buildd --arch amd64 lucid /mnt/ubuntu http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/` and chroot'd into /mnt/ubuntu
Why do you want to know, ultimately?  Are you following a guide that only claims to work on server or desktop? or what?
the 10.04 server has 5 years LTS, the 10.04 desktop has 3 years LTS

That's correct.  But it's a bit more complicated than that.  It's just that "server" packages are supported for five years, and ones that haven't been designated as "server" are only supported for three.
So, in four years, you might find that some packages you use (even on a "server" install) aren't being updated anymore
I see, so there's just one "lucid" install, and only packages are either "server" or "desktop" ?
Not even "either" but yeah.  Some packages have a longer support (5 years) than others.
by the way, how do I install dialog? I tried apt-get install dialog, and it errors "Package dialog is not available, but is referred to by another package"
'dialog' is in universe, you likely don't have all of the official repositories (if any) configured right now.
where do I get the list?
http://repogen.simplylinux.ch/  You want all four of the "branches" (don't need the source versions) and "updates" and "security" for updates (again, not the sources).
Mmm, hold on.  That seems to be giving me issues.
http://paste.ubuntu.com/496729/  that goes into your /etc/apt/sources.list
I copied your sources, but it still gives me an error when trying to apt-get install dialog
after you did that, do `sudo apt-get update`, then try and install
ah, now it works
what package do I need that "hints" what package I should install whenever I type a command that's not in my path?
command-not-found
thanks, and what apt-cache command do I use to find a package that provides a certain file? i.e. if I want file "foo.so"
